title: Apple's Next-Generation Vision Pro 2 Headset Rumors: Project Alaska Features Revealed
originSummary: Rumors are circulating about Apple's next-generation Vision Pro 2 headset, codenamed "Project Alaska," which is expected to have design changes and hardware upgrades compared to the first-generation model.
Changes include simpler rear straps and the addition of a possible external speaker.
The Vision Pro 2 is speculated to have two micro-OLED displays, a TrueDepth camera, computer vision cameras, RGB cameras, and other features.
The release date is not expected until 2025 at the earliest, and it may feature Apple's flagship M3 Max chipset.

title: Apple Introduces Spatial Video Recording on iPhone 15 Pro and 15 Pro Max with iOS 17.2 Beta 2
originSummary: Apple has introduced spatial video recording in iOS 17.2 beta 2, enabling users to capture spatial videos on the iPhone 15 Pro and 15 Pro Max.
The recorded spatial videos can be viewed on the upcoming Apple Vision Pro headset, set to be released in 2024.

Spatial videos are recorded in 1080p resolution using the main and ultrawide cameras, and they require 130MB of storage per minute. This feature is distinct from Samsung's oneUI6's 360 audio video recording feature.

title: Apple's Project Alaska: Second-Generation Vision Pro Headset with Promising Upgrades
originSummary: Apple is working on a second-generation AR/VR headset, internally known as Project Alaska.
The headset will have a similar design to the first-generation Vision Pro but with some changes, including a flat temple design and different speaker placement.
The Project Alaska headset will feature 2 micro-OLED displays, multiple cameras, and connectivity options like Wi-Fi and Bluetooth 5.
It is expected to undergo validation testing in 2025 and could potentially be released in late 2025 or early 2026.
The headset aims to bring notable design and hardware enhancements to Apple's AR/VR lineup.

One of the most exciting things about Apple's newest AirPods Pro, apart from its USB-C charging capability, is the support for wireless lossless audio when used with the upcoming Apple Vision Pro headset. For serious listeners who understand the limitations of Bluetooth as it pertains to wireless lossless audio transmission, this is the holy grail. This is the problem that the industry has been trying to solve for years but never did. So how did Apple do it? In true Apple fashion, the company is coy and vague about what's exactly going on. But we now know that this feature is possible because of Apple's H2 chip, which the AirPods Pro and the Apple Vision Pro both have. In an interview, Ron Huang, VP of Sensing and Connectivity, elaborated that the two chips are communicating using a custom-developed protocol that's "inspired by Bluetooth." It's possible that we'll see more devices support wireless lossless audio with the AirPods Pro. But instead of running at 2.4GHz which Bluetooth uses, it's running at 5GHz. The higher frequency provides sufficient bandwidth (lossless audio holds considerably more data) and a cleaner transmission that has lower latency and is less prone to interruptions such as skipping audio and random dropouts. When asked about how battery life is impacted because of the higher transfer rate, Apple says it isn't and that users can expect the same type of battery life (up to 6 hours on a single charge). If I had to guess, I'd say the close proximity of the AirPods Pro and the Vision Pro headset allows Apple to transmit at lower energy levels to conserve battery. Apple revealed little else and did not say if they are looking to expand this feature to other devices like iPhones and Macs. But it seems like a possibility given that all music on Apple Music is available in lossless. As I said before, Apple Music promoting lossless audio is great, there was no way to enjoy it on any AirPods because of the limitations of Bluetooth. But at least we know now that the future could be diifferent and that Apple's H2 chip holds the key. Kenny Yeo / Associate Editor Specifications are not everything. It's what you do with what you have that matters. originSummary: Apple has addressed the issue of wireless lossless audio on its USB-C AirPods Pro by creating a custom protocol that operates at 5GHz.
The higher frequency enables better bandwidth, cleaner transmission, lower latency, and fewer interruptions.
The feature is made possible by Apple's H2 chip, found in both the AirPods Pro and the upcoming Apple Vision Pro headset. It's uncertain if other devices will have this capability.

title: Apple Introduces Xreal Air AR Glasses for iPhone 15, Enhancing the Digital Experience
originSummary: Apple has launched the Xreal Air AR glasses, an accessory for the iPhone 15 that enhances the digital experience.
Priced between $300 and $500, these glasses feature a 120Hz MicrOLED display that reflects onto the lenses, allowing users to view digital content and the real world simultaneously.
The glasses can be easily set up with the iPhone 15 and are compatible with gaming controllers, making them suitable for gaming enthusiasts.

title: Apple's Second-Gen Vision Pro Leaked: Redesigned for Affordability and Enhanced Features, Launch Expected in 2025
originSummary: Apple's upcoming Vision Pro mixed reality headset is rumored to have a redesigned physical appearance, including flatter temples and simpler straps.
The new headset is aimed at being more cost-effective to manufacture and affordable for customers.
It will come equipped with a range of sensors, such as cameras, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth 5, and microLED displays, along with advanced features like a TrueDepth camera and low-light infrared illuminators.
The Vision Pro 2 is projected to undergo product validation testing in 2025, with a release expected in late 2025 or early 2026.
